Jason,
 
Isn't the probability of crossover a Dirac delta?  Meaning that cr=
ossover
may not be performed on each gene?
 
Ken


  _____  

From: neat@ya=
hoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Jason
Gauci
Sent: =
Monday, November 10, 2008 7:17 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] =
Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?



Initial results fro=
m running with crossover working as you described
look worse than with the =
old way; however, I think that the mutation
rates need to be tweaked becaus=
e now mutations in individuals quickly
spread throughout the species.

I'm =
going to try to play with the mutation rates and see if I can get
it to wor=
k better, but I think it might actually work better without
performing cros=
sover on each gene.

I'll let you know what I find out.

Jason G.

> > Subject:=
 [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
> > 
> > The q=
uestion about crossover in NEAT is interesting. Although it does
> > not pr=
ovide a huge boost in performance, it is still a significant
> > advance co=
mpared to what came before in neuroevolution, which is why
> > it is still =
a payoff. The competing conventions problem (also called
> > the "topology =
matching problem") was a huge issue in neuroevolution
> > before NEAT, and =
because of it some researchers were questioning
> > whether there was any h=
ope for crossover at all in such systems. It
> > could be shown in prior sy=
stems without historical marking that
> > crossover actually hurts the evol=
ution of neural networks, making its
> > prospects dim. Angeline and Pollac=
k even introduced a neuroevolution
> > method called GNARL (before NEAT) th=
at didn't even have crossover as
> > an operator because of the concern. In=
 this context, NEAT made
> > crossover safe for neuroevolution and removed =
its stigma in such
> > systems. That is, it switched it from a liability to=
 an advantage
> > that boosts performance a bit in NEAT. So it's an advance=
 in that
sense.
> > 
> > However, while the "bit" of performance gain (vs. =
having no crossover)
> > *is* likely statistically significant, it is not h=
uge. The real
> > benefit of historical markings
> > is that it enables spe=
ciation, which does have a dramatic effect
> > because of protecting innova=
tion to support complexification.
> > Crossover is more like icing on the c=
ake. However, I think many
> > people identify NEAT with crossover because =
it is such a clear
> > demonstration of the benefit of historical markings.=
 In that sense,
> > it is perhaps conceptually more significant than it is =
functionally.
> > Still, I would recommend keeping it if you can, since it =
does appear
> > to be better to have it than not, albeit not enormously.
> =
> 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com=
> com, Jeff Clune
<jclune@> wrote:
> >> 
> >> Thanks Ken. I was guessing th=
e same thing based on (1). I can't
> > think of any
> >> good reason at the=
 moment why crossover would help/hurt HyperNEAT
> > more than
> >> P-NEAT. =

> >> 
> >> (2) surprises me, however. Isn't one of the hallmarks of NEAT t=
he
> >> intelligent crossover via historical markings? I guess I just
> > a=
ssumed that
> >> had been shown to provide a huge payoff. If crossover does=
n't help
> > that much
> >> in NEAT, how much does *intelligent* (vs. na=EF=
=BF=BDve) crossover help?
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> 
> >> Cheers,
> >> J=

omChoice has
> >>>>>>> to be random every time you refer to it. If it is no=
t random
(i.e.
> >>>>>>> outside the big loop) then you choose links from e=
ither parent.
> >>> But if
> >>>>>>> it is inside the loop, then you choose=
 a gene randomly from
either
> >>>>>>> parent. Check this out and you will =
have a clearer picture if
> >>> there is
> >>>>>>> a bug or not.
> >>>>>> 
=
> >>>>>> Thanks Petar. I am confident that HyperNEAT 2.5 chooses the
parent=

> >>>>> outside

rent1 or
parent2.
> >>>>> What I am
> >>>>>> trying to find out is whether =
this is by design, or if it is
a bug.

else) happen to know how it works in other NEAT
> >>>>> packages,

in particular Ken's original NEAT code? My guess is that we are

posed to

ose packages, of

r a little while and was wondering

> >>>>>> knew =
off the top of your heads.

eeper one. In this case you must

> >>>>>>> that individuals shou=
ld not mate with themselves or such
ones that
> >>>>>>> have zero compatibi=
lity distance. Or at least try a few hundred
> >>> times
> >>>>>>> to find =
a different mate :) Hey, I say this to all users.
> > Don't use
> >>>>>>> r=
and(), fuck that, use the Mersenne Twister instead. I noticed
> >>> that in=

> >>>>>>> enhances performance!
> >>>>>>

now I am more focused on the more

nks for the suggestions, though. I will delve into them

eneticIndividual.cpp

 that goes through

hooseFirstParent =3D

hooseFirstParent)

ne(*link2));

> >>>>>>>>> Well I don't know about t=
he exact implementations of
> > HyperNEAT you
> >>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>> usi=
ng (note that P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations
> >>>>>>>>> disab=
led), but in principle crossover should choose genes
> > randomly
> >>>>>>>=
>> from both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the
> > child. In
>=
 >>>>>>>>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually do a
> =
>>>>>>> regular
> >>>>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other net=
works based
> > on the
> >>>>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is, you on=
ly mate and mutate the
> >>>>>>> CPPNs.
> >>>>>>>>> But in the case you get=
 lots of individuals with equal
> > fitness, I
> >>>>>>>>> guess these indi=
viduals are clones. Perhaps the code
frequently
> >>>>>>>>> chooses the sam=
e individuals for mating? You can try to
> > avoid this
> >>>>>>> by
> >>>>=
>>>>> introducing a loop in which you try candidates for a
> > "father" tha=
t
> >>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>> not compatible with the mother, that is, when t=
heir
> > compatibility
> >>>>>>>>> distance is 0.00, try again. There is an=
other possibility,
> > simply
> >>>>>>>>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN =
and therefore the produced
> >>>>>>> network is
> >>>>>>>>> changed in such=
 a magnitude that is has no chance for
> > survival and
> >>>>>>> is
> >>>>=
>>>>> discarded. Even though there is speciation.
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> =
Peter
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailt=
o:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com,
Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> =
>>>>>>>>>> Hello all-
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Does crossover do anything=
 in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> PNEAT:
> >>>>>>>>>> If =
I am reading the code correctly, during crossover, if the
> >>>>>>>>> subst=
rates are
> >>>>>>>>>> the same (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is=

always the
> >>>>>>> case
> >>>>>>>>> in
> >>>>>>>>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the=
 link values are taken from either
> > parent1 or
> >>>>>>>>> parent2.
> >>=
>>>>>>>> Isn't it more normal when crossing over to take some from
> > pare=
nt1
> >>>>>>>>> and some
> >>>>>>>>>> from parent2? Why grab all from just =
one?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does not=
hing, right?
It will
> >>>>>>>>> always grab
> >>>>>>>>>> the substrate of =
parent1 or the substrate of parent2. If I
> > track
> >>>>>>>>> parent and
=
> >>>>>>>>>> offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the exact
> =
> same
> >>>>>>>>> fitness as
> >>>>>>>>>> one of the two parents.
> >>>>>>=
>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> On to HyperNEAT:
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> I tracked th=
e fitness of each parent and the resulting
> > offspring.
> >>>>>>>>> The o=
dd
> >>>>>>>>>> thing is that the organisms that are crossed only (i.e.
> >=
 they are
> >>>>>>>>> never
> >>>>>>>>>> mutated) have the *exact* same fit=
ness of one of their
parents
> >>>>>>>>> 98.88% of the
> >>>>>>>>>> time. I=
n 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out of 12257
that were
> >>>>>>>>> crosse=
d over
> >>>>>>>>>> and not mutated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why woul=
d
these
> >>>>>>> new
> >>>>>>>>> links
> >>>>>>>>>> have such a small impa=
ct? It turns out that this is because
> >>>>>>> nearly
> >>>>>>>>> every
> =
>>>>>>>>>> time that there is an extra link that gets placed in the
child,
=
> >>>>>>> the
> >>>>>>>>> parent
> >>>>>>>>>> that donated that link is als=
o the parent whose weights are
> > being
> >>>>>>>>> grabbed,
> >>>>>>>>>> =
meaning that the crossover is only copying the parent
> > (hence the
> >>>>=
>>>>> same
> >>>>>>>>>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should be m=
uch more
> >>>>>>>>> disruptive, no?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>=
>> As a final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs
> > with the
> =
>>>>>>>>> default
> >>>>>>>>>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' parameter set to .25=
, so 25% of orgs
> >>>>>>> never
> >>>>>>>>> are
> >>>>>>>>>> candidates fo=
r crossover. I then ran experimental treatments
> >>>>>>>>>> hyperneat-noCr=
oss and pneat-noCross where the
> >>>>>>> MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>>>>>>=
> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were crossed over.
> > Despite my
> >>=
>>>>>>> comments
> >>>>>>>>>> above, Hyperneat (with cross) did beat HyperN=
EAT-noCross,
> > however
> >>>>>>>>> the
> >>>>>>>>>> difference was not tr=
emendous (although it does seem to be
> >>>>>>>>> statistically
> >>>>>>>>>=
> significant). For p-neat, the reverse was true. Nevertheless,
> >>>>>>> t=
his
> >>>>>>>>> is not a
> >>>>>>>>>> perfect test of whether crossover pay=
s dividends, because if
> >>>>>>>>> crossover does
> >>>>>>>>>> nothing mos=
t of the time, and I increase
MutateOnlyProbability
> >>>>>>> from
> >>>>>>=
>>> .25 to
> >>>>>>>>>> 1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (onl=
y 80% of
> >>>>>>> crossed
> >>>>>>>>> orgs are
> >>>>>>>>>> also mutated).=

> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Are these the intended consequences of crossove=
r, or am I
> > missing
> >>>>>>>>> something?
> >>>>>>>>>> 
> >>>>>>>>>> Ch=
eers,

Lab, Michigan State University

  > Subject: [neat] Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT an=
d 
  PNEAT?<BR>> > <BR>> > The question about crossover in NEAT=
 is 
  interesting. Although it does<BR>> > not provide a huge boost =
in 
  performance, it is still a significant<BR>> > advance compared =
to what 
  came before in neuroevolution, which is why<BR>> > it is s=
till a payoff. 
  The competing conventions problem (also called<BR>> &g=
t; the "topology 
  matching problem") was a huge issue in neuroevolution<B=
R>> > before 
  NEAT, and because of it some researchers were questio=
ning<BR>> > whether 
  there was any hope for crossover at all in suc=
h systems. It<BR>> > could 
  be shown in prior systems without histo=
rical marking that<BR>> > 
  crossover actually hurts the evolution o=
f neural networks, making its<BR>> 
  > prospects dim. Angeline and P=
ollack even introduced a 
  neuroevolution<BR>> > method called GNARL=
 (before NEAT) that didn't even 
  have crossover as<BR>> > an operat=
or because of the concern. In this 
  context, NEAT made<BR>> > cross=
over safe for neuroevolution and removed 
  its stigma in such<BR>> >=
 systems. That is, it switched it from a 
  liability to an advantage<BR>&g=
t; > that boosts performance a bit in NEAT. 
  So it's an advance in tha=
t<BR>sense.<BR>> > <BR>> > However, while 
  the "bit" of perfo=
rmance gain (vs. having no crossover)<BR>> > *is* 
  likely statistic=
ally significant, it is not huge. The real<BR>> > 
  benefit of histo=
rical markings<BR>> > is that it enables speciation, 
  which does ha=
ve a dramatic effect<BR>> > because of protecting 
  innovation to su=
pport complexification.<BR>> > Crossover is more like 
  icing on the=
 cake. However, I think many<BR>> > people identify NEAT 
  with cros=
sover because it is such a clear<BR>> > demonstration of the 
  benef=
it of historical markings. In that sense,<BR>> > it is perhaps 
  con=
ceptually more significant than it is functionally.<BR>> > Still, I 
=
  would recommend keeping it if you can, since it does appear<BR>> > =
to be 
  better to have it than not, albeit not enormously.<BR>> > <B=
R>> > 
  ken<BR>> > <BR>> > --- In <A
